Minutes and Order Setting Settlement Status Conference. Settlement Status Conference held before Magistrate Judge Daniel E. Butcher on April 10, 2023. The attorneys for the parties have reached a settlement agreement in principle on all substantive claims. The settlement is subject to approval by City Council and affected city departments. The settlement in principle does not include Plaintiffs' attorney fees, which will be the subject of further negotiations and two Zoom Settlement Conferences with the Court before Magistrate Judge Daniel E. Butcher on May 5, 2023 at 10:00 a.m. and May 17, 2023 at 9:30 a.m. The Court requests that the parties lodge Settlement Briefs (which may be submitted confidentially) regarding Plaintiffs' attorney fees on or before May 3, 2023. The Court VACATES the hearing set on April 12, 2023. (Plaintiff Attorney Ann Menasche; Stuart Seaborn).(Defendant Attorney Lilys McCoy). (no document attached) (smd) (Entered: 04/10/2023)

case_data.name: Bloom v. City of San Diego
case_data.plaintiff_description: Plaintiffs are "all homeless persons who have been cited and/or subject to citation by the City of San Diego pursuant to San Diego Muni. Code §§ 86.0137(f);San Diego Muni. Code § 86.0139(a); and/or are at risk of arrest for illegal lodging."
settlement_agreement: Court Approved Settlement or Consent Decree
case_data.summary:
On November 15, 2017, a group of homeless individuals sued the City of San Diego, alleging that the city's enforcement of parking and vehicle habitation ordinances against them was a violation of their Eighth Amendment (cruel and unusual punishment) and Fourteenth Amendment (substantive due process, right to travel and equal protection) rights. Plaintiffs sought to certify a class consisting of "All persons in the City of San Diego who used, use, or will use an RV or other vehicle as their only form of shelter at any time after November 15, 2017". Additionally, plaintiffs requested a "Disability Sub-class" consisting of "Members who have a ‘disability’ as defined under the ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12102, which limits their ability to comply with the City’s ordinances that prevent people from using vehicles as shelter and/or which makes them particularly vulnerable to harm from the City’s enforcement of the
ordinances.” This case was presided over by Judge J. Paul Oetken. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel, the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty, and Disability Rights California, claimed the City's enforcement of its nighttime RV parking ordinance and its vehicle habitation ordinance targeted homeless vehicle owners, ticketing them and impounding their vehicles for unpaid tickets. Plaintiffs asserted that due to a housing crisis and lack of reasonable shelter options, plaintiffs were forced to use vehicles for shelter. Plaintiffs alleged that defendant's actions violated their rights under 42 U.S.C. § 1983), the Americans with Disabilities Act (42 U.S.C. § 12132), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (29 U.S.C. § 794), the U.S. and California Constitutions, and California Civil Code § 52.1 (Bane Act). 

Plaintiffs sought declaratory relief, preliminary and permanent injunctive relief to stop the enforcement of these ordinances against homeless individuals, compensatory damages, and attorneys' fees and costs. 

On February 14, 2018, plaintiffs filed an amended complaint, adding two new named plaintiffs. On February 28, 2017, defendants filed a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim. On April 30, 2018, plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary injunction. On June 7, 2018, the court denied defendant's motion to dismiss. On August 21, 2018, the court granted in part and denied in part plaintiff's motion for a preliminary injunction. On April 30, 2020, plaintiffs filed an ex parte motion for Temporary Restraining Order. On May 1, 2020 plaintiffs filed their second amended class action complaint. On May 13,2020 the court denied plaintiffs' motion for a temporary restraining order.

On December 21, 2020 plaintiffs filed a motion to certify class. On June 8, 2021, the court granted in part and denied in part plaintiffs' renewed motion for class certification. Specifically, the court certified the main class of "All persons in the City of San Diego who used, use, or will use an RV or other vehicle as their only form of shelter, anywhere, at any time, after November 15, 2017." However, the court denied the certification of the Disability Sub-Class.

On September 22, 2022 plaintiffs filed a motion for partial summary judgment, and the defendants filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings. On April 10, 2023, parties reached a settlement agreement, which received preliminary approval by the court on March 15, 2024 (and received final approval on October 10, 2024). The main terms of the settlement include defendants forgiving certain outstanding tickets for class members, limiting the enforcement of Vehicle Habitation Ordinance (VHO) such as by not enforcing it against those living in their vehicle, limiting the enforcement of the Oversized Vehicle Ordinance (OVO), expanding the City's designated parking program, and complying in good faith with ADA-related requests by class members. The Agreement did not provide monetary damages for class members, however, individual class members were still permitted to bring their own claims for monetary damages. The City agreed to pay attorneys' fees and expenses, as well as up to $25,000 in costs necessary to monitor compliance with the Settlement Agreement. 

On July 8, 2024, plaintiffs filed two unopposed motions: a motion for final approval of class action settlement and motion for attorneys' fees. On October 10, 2024, the court granted both motions. Final judgment was entered October 15, 2024, and the case was closed. 

On March 10, 2025, plaintiffs filed a motion for settlement enforcement, arguing that the defendants had not complied with the settlement agreement. Plaintiffs alleged that the city refused to remove VHO and OVO signs which misstated the terms of the settlement agreement. Plaintiffs attempted to resolve these issues through multiple meetings with the City, but they did not reached a solution. Plaintiffs requested the court to order the defendants to modify or remove these signs as well as reimburse plaintiffs for attorney's fees related to this motion.

As of April 21, 2025, the court has not yet ruled on this motion.
case_data.summary_short: Homeless individuals sued the City of San Diego on November 15, 2017. They alleged that the city's enforcement of parking and vehicle habitation ordinances violate their Eighth and Fourteenth Amendment rights due to lack of available shelters for the homeless. The parties reached a settlement agreement on March 15, 2024, however the case is currently active as plaintiffs filed a motion on March 10, 2025, asserting that the city is not complying with the terms of the agreement. The court is yet to rule on plaintiff's motion.

Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.3     Page 3 of 44
 
11 INTRODUCTION 
22   In the midst of a severe housing crisis characterized by dramatically rising 
33 rents, a shrinking affordable housing supply, long waits for housing subsidies, scarcity 
44 of shelter beds, and a homeless population that has grown 23% in five years, the City 
55 of San Diego (“the City”) is targeting its most vulnerable residents.  There are at least 
66 817 unsheltered homeless residents in San Diego, many with disabilities, who seek 
77 shelter in their recreational vehicles (“RVs”), campers, or other vehicles.  For these 
88 people, their vehicles are their only reliable, safe shelter from the elements and only 
99 place to store their belongings.  Yet, even though there are no adequate alternatives, the 
1100 City has repeatedly ticketed and harassed these individuals for seeking shelter in their 
1111 vehicles or simply for owning vehicles and having nowhere else to park.  Specifically, 
1122 the City has used its ordinance prohibiting RV parking from 2:00 AM to 6:00 AM, San 
1133 Diego  Muni.  Code  § 86.0139(a)  (“the  nighttime  RV  parking  ordinance”),  and  its 
1144 ordinance prohibiting vehicle habitation, San Diego Muni. Code § 86.0137(f) (“the 
1155 vehicle habitation ordinance”), to target homeless vehicle owners, ticketing them and 
1166 impounding their vehicles for unpaid tickets.  In addition, the City has threatened 
1177 homeless vehicle owners with arrest and misdemeanor charges for illegal lodging. 
1188   Even after being alerted to these issues, the City has refused to modify its 
1199 policies to provide an opportunity for homeless individuals to park their vehicles 
2200 legally on City streets or other public property, at least until affordable, accessible, and 
2211 medically appropriate housing is made available to them.  While failing to provide any 
2222 accommodation for homeless individuals, including those with disabilities, the City 
2233 has created an exemption to the nighttime RV parking ordinance, via a permit system, 
2244 for persons who have a physical address.  In other words, under certain circumstances, 
2255 the City allows people who are not homeless to park their RVs overnight, but imposes 
2266 penalties against those who are homeless for the same behavior. 
2277   The  City  has  carried  out  this  discriminatory,  cruel,  punitive,  and 
2288 unconstitutional  policy  against  homeless  vehicle  owners,  many  of  whom  have 
  1 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.4     Page 4 of 44
 
11 disabilities, despite the fact that these individuals have nowhere else to go.  Sky-high 
22 rents and extremely low incomes, among other factors, have excluded these City 
33 residents  from  the  housing  market.    RV  parks  are  often  as  costly  as  renting  an 
44 apartment, and so are not viable options.  “Safe lots” that allow overnight parking for 
55 homeless individuals do not accept RVs and have far fewer spaces than the number of 
66 homeless persons with vehicles in San Diego.  The number of unsheltered homeless 
77 people far outnumbers available emergency shelter beds, which are generally filled and 
88 cannot accommodate the hundreds of people who are forced to seek shelter in their 
99 vehicles.    Moreover,  emergency  and  temporary  shelter  beds  are  functionally 
1100 unavailable to many homeless people with disabilities because the conditions in the 
1111 shelter environment are not medically acceptable given those disabilities.  Homeless 
1122 vehicle owners therefore do not have either a place to seek shelter in their vehicles 
1133 legally in the City or the availability of adequate, accessible, and medically appropriate 
1144 housing that they can afford.  In addition, homeless vehicle owners have no funds with 
1155 which to pay the excessive fines associated with the nighttime RV parking and vehicle 
1166 habitation citations without jeopardizing their ability to buy food, medicine, or other 
1177 necessities.  As a result, homeless vehicle owners have had and are at risk of having 
1188 their only shelter taken away by the City for unpaid tickets. 
1199   The nighttime RV parking ordinance and vehicle habitation ordinance 
2200 both  violate  numerous  U.S.  and  State  Constitutional  rights,  including  the  Eighth 
2211 Amendment  prohibition  on  Cruel  and  Unusual  Punishment  and  the  Fourteenth 
2222 Amendment Substantive Due Process protections, including the prohibition on reckless 
2233 endangerment; the Right to Equal Protection; and the Right to Travel.  The vehicle 
2244 habitation ordinance is also so vague and ambiguously worded that neither homeless 
2255 individuals nor anyone else can ascertain what is or is not prohibited or how to comply 
2266 with the ordinance to avoid receiving a ticket or having their vehicle impounded.  In 
2277 addition, enforcement of the ordinances discriminates against homeless vehicle owners 
2288 based on disability in violation of the antidiscrimination protections of Title II of the 
  2 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.5     Page 5 of 44
 
11 Americans with Disabilities Act and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. 
22   Rather than adequately accommodating this homeless, largely disabled 
33 group of individuals and complying with statutory and constitutional requirements, the 
44 City has instead chosen to place the health, safety, and lives of homeless vehicle owners 
55 in further jeopardy, in the hope that the continuing and escalating harassment will force 
66 these residents simply to leave town. 
77   Plaintiffs seek a Court order requiring that the City put an end to these 
88 harmful, discriminatory, and unconstitutional practices against this defenseless group 
99 of individuals. 
1100 JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
1111   The Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant 28 U.S.C. § 1331 and 
1122 1343, 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 42 U.S.C. § 1983 because Plaintiffs’ claims arise under 
1133 the laws and Constitution of the United States.  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1367, this 
1144 Court has supplemental jurisdiction over the state law and state constitutional claims 
1155 because Plaintiffs’ state claims are related to Plaintiffs’ federal claims, arise out of a 
1166 common nucleus of operative facts and form part of the same case or controversy under 
1177 Article III of the U.S. Constitution. 
1188   Venue is proper in the Southern District of California because Defendants 
1199 reside in the District and all events given rise to Plaintiffs’ claims occurred in the 
2200 District.  The relief Plaintiffs seek is within this Court’s power to grant. 
2211 PARTIES 
2222 A.  Plaintiffs 
2233   Plaintiff MICHAEL BLOOM is 68 years-old and a life-long resident of 
2244 the City of San Diego.  Mr. Bloom previously worked as an electrician and carpenter 
2255 but suffered several accidents that left him with a severely damaged arm and foot, and 
2266 led to his suffering from hypoglycemia and severe depression.  Because of these 
2277 debilitating physical and mental health issues, Mr. Bloom has not been able to engage 
2288 in gainful employment since his last accident in 1982.  His sole source of income is 
  3 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.6     Page 6 of 44
 
11 Social Security benefits, and he cannot afford market rents in San Diego.  Even if Mr. 
22 Bloom were able to locate an open bed at an emergency or temporary shelter, which 
33 are generally full and cannot accommodate the hundreds of homeless people who 
44 currently seek shelter in their vehicles, it would be functionally unavailable to him 
55 because his physical disabilities require him to lie down frequently during the day and 
66 the overcrowding and lack of privacy would worsen his mental health condition.  As a 
77 result, for the last ten years, his only available shelter has been his RV.  Mr. Bloom is 
88 not able to park his RV in the existing City “safe lots” because the “safe lots” do not 
99 allow RVs.  Despite this, and even though he has a disability placard on his vehicle, 
1100 Mr. Bloom has received at least a dozen tickets for parking his RV at night on city 
1111 streets, about five tickets for vehicle habitation, and has been threatened with arrest for 
1122 vehicle habitation.  When he has paid these tickets, Mr. Bloom has not had enough 
1133 money to pay for food or gasoline.  If Mr. Bloom does not pay the tickets, however, 
1144 the City may impound his RV, which would be devastating for his mental and physical 
1155 health and put him at far greater physical risk.  It would also leave Mr. Bloom without 
1166 the  only  form  of  shelter  available  to  him.    Mr.  Bloom  meets  the  definition  of 
1177 “chronically homeless” as defined by the regulations issued by the U.S. Department of 
1188 Housing and Urban Development (HUD).  24 C.F.R. § 91.5(1).  Mr. Bloom is also a 
1199 qualified  individual  with  disabilities  within  the  meaning  of  the  Americans  With 
2200 Disabilities Act (“ADA”), 42 U.S.C. § 12102, and the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 
2211 U.S.C. § 706(8). 
2222   Plaintiff STEPHEN CHATZKY is 70 years old and resides in the City of 
2233 San Diego with his domestic partner, Suzonne Keith, and her disabled adult daughter.  
2244 Mr. Chatzky is a lawyer, but his Attention Deficit Disorder and memory problems have 
2255 made it difficult for him practice law.  As a result, since 2002, his sole source of income 
2266 has been Social Security benefits, and he cannot afford market rents in San Diego.  
2277 Even if Mr. Chatzky were able to locate an open bed at a temporary or emergency 
2288 shelter, which are generally filled and cannot accommodate the hundreds of homeless 
  4 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.7     Page 7 of 44
 
11 people forced to seek shelter in their vehicles, it would be functionally unavailable to 
22 him because shelter conditions would force the family to separate.  A psychologist who 
33 evaluated Mr. Chatzky opined that if Mr. Chatzky were separated from his family, it 
44 would worsen his mental health condition.  Additionally, Mr. Chatzky has asthma and 
55 sleep apnea and is prone to lung infections.  Shelters typically reek of tobacco smoke, 
66 which make it difficult for him to breathe and put him at risk for lung infections.  
77 Because of these circumstances, the family has lived in an RV since 2008.  The City of 
88 San Diego impounded the family’s first RV for failure to pay tickets, including tickets 
99 for  nighttime  RV  parking  and  vehicle  habitation,  even  though  the  family  had  a 
1100 disability placard on the vehicle at that time.  After the impoundment, the family had 
1111 no regular shelter, and they were forced to sleep cramped in a car for five months until 
1122 they were able to obtain another RV through a family member’s assistance.  Because 
1133 Mr. Chatzky and Ms. Keith live in an RV, they are unable to utilize existing City “safe 
1144 lots” because “safe lots” do not accept RVs.  As a result, Mr. Chatzky and Ms. Keith 
1155 continue to receive tickets for parking their RV at night.  Mr. Chatzky meets the 
1166 definition of “chronically homeless” as defined by HUD regulations and is a qualified 
1177 individual with disabilities within the meaning of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act. 
1188   Plaintiff SUZONNE KEITH is 68 years old and a resident of the City of 
1199 San Diego.  Ms. Keith has held a range of government jobs, including as an equal rights 
2200 investigator, but her disabilities have made her unable to engage in gainful employment 
2211 for the last 19 years.  She has severe arthritis and edema that interfere with her ability 
2222 to stand or walk, depression, and Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (“PTSD”) from 
2233 having survived domestic violence prior to meeting Mr. Chatzky, and debilitating 
2244 migraines.  Ms. Keith’s sole source of income is a pension of $400 per month, and she 
2255 cannot afford market rents in San Diego.  As a result, Ms. Keith’s only option for shelter 
2266 has been to live in an RV with Mr. Chatzky and her daughter.  After the couple’s first 
2277 RV was impounded for not paying parking tickets, the couple slept cramped in a car 
2288 for five months.  Because the police continue to ticket the couple, Ms. Keith is terrified 
  5 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.8     Page 8 of 44
 
11 that the City will also impound their second RV, which is the only form of shelter 
22 available to her.  Even if Ms. Keith were able to locate an open bed at a temporary or 
33 emergency shelter, which are generally filled and cannot accommodate the hundreds 
44 of homeless people forced to seek shelter in their vehicles, it would be functionally 
55 unavailable to her because it would require that Ms. Keith be separated from Mr. 
66 Chatzky and her adult daughter, triggering her trauma symptoms and worsening her 
77 depression.  Additionally, the conditions of shelters, including the high noise level, 
88 triggers migraines for Ms. Keith.  When Ms. Keith is suffering from a debilitating 
99 migraine, she needs to rest in a private and dark space, which is usually not available 
1100 at shelters.  Ms. Keith is a qualified individual with disabilities within the meaning of 
1111 the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act and meets the definition of “chronically homeless” 
1122 as defined by the HUD regulations. 
1133   Plaintiff TONY DIAZ is 58 years old and a resident of the City of San 
1144 Diego.  Mr. Diaz worked as a welder until 2011, when worsening pain and other 
1155 symptoms of his anxiety disorder, diabetes, hypertension, severe respiratory problems, 
1166 and bad knee and shoulder prevented him from working.  He also recently had major 
1177 heart surgery.  Mr. Diaz has been homeless for approximately five years and owns a 
1188 pick-up  truck  with  a  shell  that  serves  as  his  only  shelter  and  place  to  keep  his 
1199 belongings.  He has no regular income, and he cannot afford market rents in San Diego.  
2200 Mr. Diaz has received four vehicle habitation tickets, even though he spends nights 
2211 parked at a local 7-Eleven store with the permission of the manager and does not sleep 
2222 in his vehicle when it is parked on City property.  On August 25, 2016 at approximately 
2233 6:30 a.m., Mr. Diaz came out of a bathroom in a public park when a member of the San 
2244 Diego Police Department issued him a vehicle habitation ticket.  Mr. Diaz explained to 
2255 the officer that he had just arrived to go fishing and told the officer that he was disabled 
2266 and had just had heart surgery.  The officer nonetheless issued the ticket and threatened 
2277 to ticket him anytime he saw Mr. Diaz’s vehicle.  The officer also threatened to have 
2288 Mr. Diaz arrested for vehicle habitation.  Since that incident, police officers have 
  6 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.9     Page 9 of 44
 
11 continued to harass and ticket Mr. Diaz under the vehicle habitation ordinance.  Mr. 
22 Diaz has done his best to comply with the vehicle habitation ordinance by parking 
33 overnight on private property with the owner’s permission but does not understand 
44 what he needs to do in order to stop the ticketing.  Even if Mr. Diaz were able to locate 
55 an open bed at a temporary or emergency shelter, which are generally full and cannot 
66 accommodate the hundreds of homeless people forced to seek shelter in their vehicles, 
77 it would be functionally unavailable to him because the tobacco smoke, cleaning fluid 
88 odors, and lack of fresh air would aggravate his respiratory condition.  Moreover, the 
99 crowded, noisy, and regimented environment of shelters would worsen his symptoms 
1100 of anxiety.  Mr. Diaz is a qualified individual with disabilities within the meaning of 
1111 the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.  He also meets the definition of “chronically 
1122 homeless” as defined by HUD regulations. 
1133   Plaintiff VALERIE GRISCHY is 58 years old and a resident of the City 
1144 of San Diego.  Ms. Grischy was a licensed chiropractor and had a successful career, 
1155 until she became disabled by a serious car accident in 2009.  Since shortly after the 
1166 accident, she has been unable to work due to severe back pain, depression, anxiety, and 
1177 panic attacks stemming from a traumatic brain injury and PTSD.  Ms. Grischy’s sole 
1188 source of income is Supplementary Security Income (SSI), and she cannot afford 
1199 market rents in San Diego.  Because she has not been able to afford housing, Ms. 
2200 Grischy has been living in her RV since 2012.  She has received tickets from the City 
2211 of San Diego for vehicle habitation and nighttime RV parking even though she has a 
2222 disability placard on the vehicle.  Ms. Grischy has tried to find places to park, driving 
2233 up to 30 miles a day, in an attempt to avoid being ticketed.  Despite her efforts, Ms. 
2244 Grischy continued to receive written warnings and tickets from police.  Paying these 
2255 parking tickets would be a severe financial hardship for her.  The threat of ticketing 
2266 also forced her to leave San Diego temporarily, which she considers her home, to avoid 
2277 further ticketing.  Even if Ms. Grischy were able to locate an open bed at a temporary 
2288 or emergency shelter, which are generally full and cannot accommodate the hundreds 
  7 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.10     Page 10 of
44
 
11 of homeless people forced to seek shelter in their vehicles, it would be functionally 
22 unavailable to her because her medical history and medical needs require that she live 
33 alone.  Communal shelter life is simply untenable.  The current City “safe lots” are not 
44 an option for Ms. Grischy because RVs are not allowed in those lots.  Ms. Grischy is a 
55 qualified  individual  with  disabilities  within  the  meaning  of  the  ADA  and  the 
66 Rehabilitation Act.  She also meets the definition of “chronically homeless” as defined 
77 by HUD regulations. 
88   Plaintiff PENNY “GRACE” HELMS is 58 years old and a resident of the 
99 City of San Diego.  Ms. Helms supported herself throughout her 20s working as a 
1100 waiter and dancer.  At the age of 29, the long-term effects of chronic illnesses, and the 
1111 physical and emotional trauma that she experienced as a child, became so debilitating 
1122 that she had to stop working.  Ms. Helms suffers from fibromyalgia; chronic fatigue 
1133 syndrome; arthritis; six bulging disks; hypersensitivity and allergy to environmental 
1144 pollutants such as cigarette smoke and perfume; and various neurological disorders 
1155 including PTSD, hypervigilance, emotional hypersensitivity, and dissociative identity 
1166 disorder.  Over the past two decades, she has tried to earn a living by working as a 
1177 house cleaner, dog groomer, among other jobs, whenever her disabilities permit.  But 
1188 none of that income has been steady or sufficient for her to support herself, and that 
1199 income has only fallen over the years.  Ms. Helms’ main, and often the only, source of 
2200 income for the past few years has been Social Security disability benefits.  She cannot 
2211 afford market rents in San Diego.  Because of this, Ms. Helms had been forced to seek 
2222 shelter in her RV.  She has been threatened multiple times by police with ticketing for 
2233 vehicle habitation and impoundment for living in her RV.  She has also been threatened 
2244 with arrest for encroachment near her RV.  The threat of receiving citations she cannot 
2255 afford to pay, impoundment, and arrest terrifies her and exacerbates her disabilities, 
2266 including her hypervigilance.  She has recently left San Diego for periods of weeks due 
2277 to her fear of being ticketed, arrested, and having her RV impounded.  Ms. Helms 
2288 currently does not have a place in San Diego where she can safely park or seek shelter 
  8 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.11     Page 11 of
44
 
11 in her RV.  Even if Ms. Helms were able to locate an open bed at a temporary or 
22 emergency shelter, which are generally full and cannot accommodate the hundreds of 
33 homeless people forced to seek shelter in their vehicles, it would be functionally 
44 unavailable to her because she cannot tolerate communal living given her myriad 
55 disabilities.  The current City “safe lots” are not an option for Ms. Helms because RVs 
66 are not allowed.  Ms. Helms is a qualified individual with disabilities within the 
77 meaning of the ADA, and the Rehabilitation Act.  She also meets the definition of 
88 “chronically homeless” as defined by HUD regulations. 
99   Plaintiff BENJAMIN HERNANDEZ is a 54-year-old man and a resident 
1100 of the City of San Diego.  Mr. Hernandez was a stonemason and primary breadwinner 
1111 for his family until he was involved in a pedestrian accident in 2015.  After the accident, 
1122 the orthopedic impairments from his injuries, along with depression, left him unable to 
1133 work.  Mr. Hernandez was only given a small, one-time disability award and does not 
1144 receive ongoing disability benefits.  Though his wife works, her wages are extremely 
1155 modest and insufficient to afford the high cost of housing in San Diego.  Their lack of 
1166 funds has caused Mr. Hernandez and his wife to utilize their RV as their primary shelter 
1177 for the past year.  On July 26, 2017, however, the City impounded their RV for unpaid 
1188 nighttime RV parking citations.  Since they cannot afford to pay the citations in order 
1199 to retrieve their RV from impoundment, the couple is now forced to use his truck as 
2200 shelter from the elements.  Now in his truck, Mr. Hernandez remains at risk for vehicle 
2211 habitation tickets.  Even if Mr. Hernandez were able to locate an open bed at a 
2222 temporary or emergency shelter, which are generally full and cannot accommodate the 
2233 hundreds of homeless people forced to seek shelter in their vehicles, it would be 
2244 functionally unavailable to him because it would force him to separate from his wife, 
2255 significantly worsening his depression.  Mr. Hernandez is a qualified individual with 
2266 disabilities within the meaning of the Rehabilitation Act, the ADA, and California law.  
2277 He also meets the definition of “chronically homeless” as defined by the regulations 
2288 issued by HUD. 
  9 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.12     Page 12 of
44
 
11   Plaintiff DOUG HIGGINS is 68 years old, a resident of the City of San 
22 Diego, and a veteran who was honorably discharged from the U.S. Army.  He had a 
33 successful career as a car dealer until his symptoms of anxiety and depression, along 
44 with a painful back condition, worsened in 2009.  His bad back, which is aggravated 
55 by stress, keeps him from standing, sitting, or walking for any length of time.  His sole 
66 source of income is Social Security benefits, and he cannot afford to pay market rent 
77 in San Diego.  Even if Mr. Higgins were able to locate an open bed at a temporary or 
88 emergency shelter, which are generally full and cannot accommodate the hundreds of 
99 homeless people forced to seek shelter in their vehicles, it would be functionally 
1100 unavailable to him because it would exacerbate his mental health symptoms.  For the 
1111 past three years, his RV has been the only shelter available to him.  Mr. Higgins has 
1122 received tickets both for vehicle habitation and for nighttime RV parking, but paying 
1133 the tickets jeopardizes his ability to pay for food and other necessities.  The threat of 
1144 ticketing and fear of losing his RV to impoundment increases his stress and exacerbates 
1155 the symptoms of his disabilities.  Police have told him to leave the City if he does not 
1166 like the ticketing, but he considers San Diego to be his home.  Mr. Higgins is a qualified 
1177 individual with disabilities within the meaning of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.  
1188 Mr. Higgins also meets the definition of “chronically homeless” as defined by the 
1199 regulations issued by HUD.

1100   There is also a strong link between homelessness and disability.  The U.S.

1155 adequate nighttime residence.  This includes persons who use RVs or other vehicles 
1166 for other than temporary living quarters for recreational use.  42 U.S.C. § 11302(a)(1); 
1177 24 C.F.R. § 3282.8(g).  The Regional Task Force found that 31% of the City’s homeless 
1188 population was “chronically homeless.”  (2017 We All Count Results, supra at 16.)

2233 one-day resource fair for the homeless in the City, 60.2% reported a long lasting 
2244 medical condition and 49.5% reported having a mental illness.  San Diego Housing

1166   The City’s “Prohibition of Use of Streets for Storage, Service or Sale of 
1177 Vehicles or For Habitation” ordinance, San Diego Muni. Code § 86.0137(f), provides: 
1188 “It is unlawful for any person to use a vehicle while it is parked or standing on any 
1199 streets as either temporary or permanent living quarters, abode, or place of habitation.”  
2200 The terms “temporary or permanent living quarters, abode, or place of habitation” are 
2211 not defined.  A ticket for vehicle habitation is punishable as an infraction by a fine of 
2222 $40 plus a $12.50 surcharge and doubles if not paid in 21 days.  
2233   The City’s “Prohibition of Parking of Oversized, Non-Motorized and 
2244 Recreational Vehicles” ordinance, San Diego Muni. Code § 86.0139(a), provides in 
2255 relevant part: “Except as provided in section 86.0140 or otherwise expressly provided 
2266 to the contrary herein, or unless such parking or standing is authorized by the City 
2277 Manager and appropriate sign permitting such parking or standing are posted: (a) it is 
2288 unlawful for any person to park or leave standing upon any public street, park road or

1122   Title II of the ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12132, provides that: 
1133 [N]o qualified individual with a disability shall, by reason of such disability, be

2211 includes within its scope “anything a public entity does.”  Yeskey v. Pennsylvania Dep’t

2277 including San Diego’s parks, beaches and public events are “services, programs, or 
2288 activities” of the City. 
  36 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.39     Page 39 of
44
 
11   Title II protects people with disabilities against facially neutral policies 
22 that burden people with disabilities more than others, by requiring that the public entity 
33 provide reasonable modifications to avoid the discrimination unless the public entity

55 program.  28 C.F.R. § 35.130(b)(7); Crowder v. Kitagaw, 81 F. 3d 1480 (9th Cir. 1996). 
66   Reasonable modifications can adjust for the financial limitations that arise 
77 from a disability, not just the immediate manifestations of the impairment giving rise 
88 to the disability.  Giebeler v. M & B Associates, 343 F. 3d 1143, 1152 (9th Cir. 2003). 
99   By refusing to reasonably modify their policies and practices as described 
1100 herein to allow Named Plaintiffs and Disability Subclass members to legally park their 
1111 vehicles on City streets or other public property and to utilize their vehicles for shelter, 
1122 at least until affordable, accessible and medically appropriate housing is available for 
1133 them,  Defendants  have  violated  and  continue  to  violate  the  antidiscrimination 
1144 requirements of Title II of the ADA. 
1155   Title II regulations interpreting the ADA prohibit a public entity from 
1166 utilizing  criteria  or  methods  of  administration  that  have  the  effect  of  subjecting 
1177 qualified individuals with disabilities to discrimination based on disability.  29 C.F.R. 
1188 § 35.130(b)(3). 
1199   A public entity is also prohibited from imposing eligibility criteria that 
2200 screen out or tend to screen out individuals with disabilities from fully and equally 
2211 enjoying any service, program, or activity.  28 C.F.R. § 35.130(b)(8). 
2222   Defendants’ policies and practices in administrating their parking program 
2233 through  ticketing  Disability  Subclass  members,  impounding  their  RVs  and  other 
2244 vehicles and excluding homeless RV owners from the ability to obtain parking permits 
2255 available to people with physical addresses, has the effect of discriminating against and 
2266 imposing disproportionate burdens on people with disabilities based on disability, 
2277 screening out such persons from the benefits of the City’s parking program, and 
2288 denying them meaningful access to such benefits and to the City’s amenities enjoyed 
  37 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.40     Page 40 of
44
 
11 by and available to people without disabilities. 
22   In carrying out Defendants’ policies and practices as described herein, 
33 Defendants have utilized criteria or methods of administration that have the effect of 
44 subjecting qualified individuals with disabilities to discrimination based on disability.  
55 29 C.F.R. § 35.130(b)(3). 
66   In carrying out Defendants’ policies and practices as herein described and 
77 denying Plaintiffs’ request for reasonable modification in violation of Plaintiffs’ rights 
88 under the ADA, Defendants have acted knowingly and with deliberate indifference to 
99 the harm substantially likely to occur. 
1100   As a result of Defendants’ unlawful acts, Named Plaintiffs have suffered 
1111 and  continue  to  suffer  injuries,  including  emotional  injuries,  and  are  entitled  to 
1122 compensatory damages, including damages for emotional distress.  In addition, Named 
1133 Plaintiffs and Disability Subclass members are entitled to injunctive and declaratory 
1144 relief, restitution, and attorneys’ fees and costs. 
1155 NINTH CAUSE OF ACTION 
1166 Violation of § 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973  
1177 (29 U.S.C. § 794) 
1188 (On Behalf of Disability Subclass Members) 
1199   Plaintiffs hereby incorporate each and every allegation contained in the 
2200 foregoing paragraphs as if fully set forth herein. 
2211   Defendants City of San Diego and the San Diego Police Department are 
2222 recipients of financial assistance from the federal government. 
2233   Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 requires that qualified 
2244 persons  with  disabilities  be  provided  with  meaningful  access  to  federally  funded 
2255 programs.  In order to assure meaningful access, reasonable modifications may be 
2266 required  unless  the  recipient  of  federal  funding  can  demonstrate  that  such 
2277 modifications would result in a fundamental alteration in the nature of the program.  29 
2288 U.S.C. § 749; 24 C.F.R. §§ 8.3 and 8.4; Alexander v. Choate, 469 U.S. 287, 301 (1985). 
  38 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.41     Page 41 of
44
 
11   Defendants’ actions and omissions as herein stated have denied Plaintiffs’ 
22 and Disability Subclass members’ right to reasonable modifications thereby denying 
33 them meaningful access to Defendants’ parking program and to the amenities that the 
44 City offers its residents without disabilities, and subjecting them to discrimination on 
55 the basis of disability, in violation of section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. 
66   As a result of Defendants’ unlawful acts in violation of the Rehabilitation 
77 Act,  Named  Plaintiffs  have  suffered  and  continue  to  suffer  injuries,  including 
88 emotional injuries, and are entitled to compensatory damages, including damages for 
99 emotional distress.  In addition, Named Plaintiffs and Disability Subclass members are 
1100 entitled to injunctive and declaratory relief, restitution, and attorneys’ fees and costs. 
1111 PRAYER FOR RELIEF 
1122   WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs pray that this Court: 
1133 A.  Declare that Defendants’ past, present, and threatened future enforcement 
1144 of the vehicle habitation and nighttime RV parking ordinances, San Diego Muni. Code 
1155 §§ 86.0137(f) and 86.0139(a), against Named Plaintiffs and Class members or any 
1166 citing, arrest or prosecution or threatened citation or arrest for lodging in vehicles on 
1177 public property violates the right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment, the 
1188 right to travel, the right to due process and equal protection of the laws; 
1199 B.  Declare that Defendants’ past, present and threatened future enforcement 
2200 of the above San Diego ordinances and threats of arrest for lodging in vehicles on 
2211 public  property  against  Named  Plaintiffs  and  Disability  Subclass  members 
2222 discriminates on the basis of disability in violation of the ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12132, and 
2233 the Rehabilitation Act, 29 U.S.C. § 794; 
2244 C.  Declare that San Diego’s vehicle habitation ordinance, San Diego Muni. 
2255 Code § 86.0137(a), is void for vagueness and unenforceable facially and/or as applied 
2266 to Named Plaintiffs and Class members pursuant to the due process protections of the 
2277 U.S. and California Constitutions; 
2288 D.  Issue a preliminary and permanent injunction, enjoining Defendants, their 
  39 Case No.   
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 1     Filed 11/15/17     PageID.42     Page 42 of
44
 
11 officers,  employees,  assignees,  successors,  and  agents  from  enforcing  the  vehicle 
22 habitation and nighttime RV parking ordinances against Named Plaintiffs and Class 
33 members through issuing of additional tickets, collecting unpaid fines associated with 
44 previous tickets issued under these ordinances, arresting Class members, or through 
55 impoundment of RVs or other vehicles for such unpaid tickets and further enjoining 
66 Defendants  against  ticketing,  arrests,  prosecutions  or  any  threats  of  arrest  or 
77 prosecution against Named Plaintiffs and Class members for lodging in vehicles on 
88 public property, until such time that permanent accessible housing that is affordable is 
99 made available to these individuals; 
1100 E.  Award restitution for fines and penalties that Defendants collected from 
1111 Named Plaintiffs and Class members and for vehicles that were impounded pursuant 
1122 to  Defendants’  enforcement  of  the  nighttime  RV  parking  and  vehicle  habitation 
1133 ordinances; 
1144 F.  Order Defendants to pay compensatory damages to Named Plaintiffs only

11 INTRODUCTION 
22   In the midst of a severe housing crisis characterized by dramatically rising 
33 rents, a shrinking affordable housing supply, long waits for housing subsidies, scarcity 
44 of shelter beds, and a homeless population that has grown 23% in five years, the City 
55 of San Diego (“the City”) is targeting its most vulnerable residents.  There are at least 
66 817 unsheltered homeless residents in San Diego, many with disabilities, who seek 
77 shelter in their recreational vehicles (“RVs”), campers, or other vehicles.  For these 
88 people, their vehicles are their only reliable, safe shelter from the elements and only 
99 place to store their belongings.  Yet, even though there are no adequate alternatives, the 
1100 City has repeatedly ticketed and harassed these individuals for seeking shelter in their 
1111 vehicles or simply for owning vehicles and having nowhere else to park.  Specifically, 
1122 the City has used its ordinance prohibiting RV parking from 2:00 AM to 6:00 AM, San 
1133 Diego  Muni.  Code  § 86.0139(a)  (“the  nighttime  RV  parking  ordinance”),  and  its 
1144 ordinance prohibiting vehicle habitation, San Diego Muni. Code § 86.0137(f) (“the 
1155 vehicle habitation ordinance”), to target homeless vehicle owners, ticketing them and 
1166 impounding their vehicles for unpaid tickets.  In addition, the City has threatened 
1177 homeless vehicle owners with arrest and misdemeanor charges for illegal lodging. 
1188   Even after being alerted to these issues, the City has refused to modify its 
1199 policies to provide an opportunity for homeless individuals to park their vehicles 
2200 legally on City streets or other public property, at least until affordable, accessible, and 
2211 medically appropriate housing is made available to them.  While failing to provide any 
2222 accommodation for homeless individuals, including those with disabilities, the City 
2233 has created an exemption to the nighttime RV parking ordinance, via a permit system, 
2244 for persons who have a physical address.  In other words, under certain circumstances, 
2255 the City allows people who are not homeless to park their RVs overnight but imposes 
2266 penalties against those who are homeless for the same behavior. 
2277   The  City  has  carried  out  this  discriminatory,  cruel,  punitive,  and 
2288 unconstitutional  policy  against  homeless  vehicle  owners,  many  of  whom  have 
  1 Case No. 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-NLS
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 14     Filed 02/14/18     PageID.90     Page 4 of
48
 
11 disabilities, despite the fact that these individuals have nowhere else to go.  Sky-high 
22 rents and extremely low incomes, among other factors, have excluded these City 
33 residents  from  the  housing  market.    RV  parks  are  often  as  costly  as  renting  an 
44 apartment, and so are not viable options.  “Safe lots” that allow overnight parking for 
55 homeless individuals do not accept RVs and have far fewer spaces than the number of 
66 homeless persons with vehicles in San Diego.  The number of unsheltered homeless 
77 people far outnumbers available emergency shelter beds, which are generally filled and 
88 cannot accommodate the hundreds of people who are forced to seek shelter in their 
99 vehicles.    At  best,  emergency  and  temporary  shelters  provide  only  transitory 
1100 accommodations, with a large majority who are exited from shelters still lacking the 
1111 permanent housing that they need.  Moreover, emergency and temporary shelter beds 
1122 are functionally unavailable to many homeless people with disabilities because the 
1133 conditions  in  the  shelter  environment  are  not  medically  acceptable  given  those 
1144 disabilities.  Homeless vehicle owners therefore do not have either a place to seek 
1155 shelter in their vehicles legally in the City or the availability of adequate, accessible, 
1166 stable and medically appropriate housing that they can afford.  In addition, homeless 
1177 vehicle owners have no funds with which to pay the excessive fines associated with 
1188 the nighttime RV parking and vehicle habitation citations without jeopardizing their 
1199 ability to buy food, medicine, or other necessities.  As a result, homeless vehicle 
2200 owners have had and are at risk of having their only shelter taken away by the City for 
2211 unpaid tickets. 
2222   The nighttime RV parking ordinance and vehicle habitation ordinance 
2233 both  violate  numerous  U.S.  and  State  Constitutional  rights,  including  the  Eighth 
2244 Amendment  prohibition  on  Cruel  and  Unusual  Punishment  and  Fourteenth 
2255 Amendment  Due  Process  protections,  including  the  prohibition  on  state-created 
2266 danger; the Right to Equal Protection; and the Right to Travel.  The vehicle habitation 
2277 ordinance is also so vague and ambiguously worded that neither homeless individuals 
2288 nor anyone else can ascertain what is or is not prohibited or how to comply with the 
  2 Case No. 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-NLS
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 14     Filed 02/14/18     PageID.91     Page 5 of
48
 
11 ordinance to avoid receiving a ticket or having their vehicle impounded.  In addition, 
22 enforcement of the ordinances discriminates against homeless vehicle owners based on 
33 disability in violation of the antidiscrimination protections of Title II of the Americans 
44 with Disabilities Act and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. 
55   Rather than adequately accommodating this homeless, largely disabled 
66 group of individuals and complying with statutory and constitutional requirements, the 
77 City has instead chosen to place the health, safety, and lives of homeless vehicle owners 
88 in further jeopardy, in the hope that the continuing and escalating harassment will force 
99 these residents simply to leave town. 
1100   Plaintiffs seek a Court order requiring that the City put an end to these 
1111 harmful, discriminatory, and unconstitutional practices against this defenseless group 
1122 of individuals. 
1133 JURISDICTION AND VENUE 
1144   The Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant 28 U.S.C. § 1331 and 
1155 1343, 42 U.S.C. § 12132 and 42 U.S.C. § 1983 because Plaintiffs’ claims arise under 
1166 the laws and Constitution of the United States.  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1367, this 
1177 Court has supplemental jurisdiction over the state law and state constitutional claims 
1188 because Plaintiffs’ state claims are related to Plaintiffs’ federal claims, arise out of a 
1199 common nucleus of operative facts and form part of the same case or controversy under 
2200 Article III of the U.S. Constitution. 
2211   Venue is proper in the Southern District of California because Defendant 
2222 resides in the District and all events given rise to Plaintiffs’ claims occurred in the 
2233 District.  The relief Plaintiffs seek is within this Court’s power to grant. 
2244 PARTIES 
2255 A.  Plaintiffs 
2266   Plaintiff MICHAEL BLOOM is 68 years-old and a life-long resident of 
2277 the City of San Diego.  Mr. Bloom previously worked as an electrician and carpenter 
2288 but suffered several accidents that left him with a severely damaged arm and foot, and 
  3 Case No. 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-NLS
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 14     Filed 02/14/18     PageID.92     Page 6 of
48
 
11 led to his suffering from hypoglycemia and severe depression.  Because of these 
22 debilitating physical and mental health issues, Mr. Bloom has not been able to engage 
33 in gainful employment since his last accident in 1982.  His sole source of income is 
44 Social Security benefits, and he cannot afford market rents in San Diego.  Even if Mr. 
55 Bloom were able to locate an open bed at an emergency or temporary shelter, which 
66 are generally full and cannot accommodate the hundreds of homeless people who 
77 currently seek shelter in their vehicles, it would be functionally unavailable to him 
88 because his physical disabilities require him to lie down frequently during the day and 
99 the overcrowding and lack of privacy would worsen his mental health condition.  As a 
1100 result, for the last ten years, his only available shelter has been his RV.  Mr. Bloom is 
1111 not able to park his RV in the existing City “safe lots” because the “safe lots” do not 
1122 allow RVs.  Despite this, and even though he has a disability placard on his vehicle, 
1133 Mr. Bloom has received at least a dozen tickets for parking his RV at night on city 
1144 streets, about five tickets for vehicle habitation, and has been threatened with arrest for 
1155 vehicle habitation.  As one example, he received a ticket on or about December 12, 
1166 2017 for violation of the nighttime RV parking ordinance.  When he has paid these 
1177 tickets, Mr. Bloom has not had enough money to pay for food or gasoline.  If Mr. Bloom 
1188 does not pay the tickets, however, the City may impound his RV, which would be 
1199 devastating for his mental and physical health and put him at far greater physical risk.  
2200 It would also leave Mr. Bloom without the only form of shelter available to him.  Mr. 
2211 Bloom meets the definition of “chronically homeless” as defined by the regulations 
2222 issued by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD).  24 C.F.R. 
2233 § 91.5(1).  Mr. Bloom is also a qualified individual with disabilities within the meaning 
2244 of  the  Americans  With  Disabilities  Act  (“ADA”),  42  U.S.C.  § 12102,  and  the 
2255 Rehabilitation Act of 1973, 29 U.S.C. § 706(8). 
2266   Plaintiff STEPHEN CHATZKY is 70 years old and resides in the City of 
2277 San Diego with his domestic partner, Suzonne Keith, and her disabled adult daughter.  
2288 Mr. Chatzky is a lawyer, but his Attention Deficit Disorder and memory problems have 
  4 Case No. 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-NLS
 
 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 14     Filed 02/14/18     PageID.93     Page 7 of
48
 
11 made it difficult for him practice law.  As a result, since 2002, his sole source of income 
22 has been Social Security benefits, and he cannot afford market rents in San Diego.  
33 Even if Mr. Chatzky were able to locate an open bed at a temporary or emergency 
44 shelter, which are generally filled and cannot accommodate the hundreds of homeless

11   The Substantive Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the 
22 U.S. Constitution provides that no state shall “deprive any person of life, liberty, or 
33 property, without due process of law.” 
44   In  order  to  satisfy  the  Due  Process  Clause,  an  ordinance  must  be 
55 sufficiently definite to provide adequate notice of the conduct proscribed and provide 
66 sufficient guidelines for the police so that arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement 
77 does not occur.  Tobe v. City of Santa Ana, 9 Cal. 4th 1069, 1106-1107 (1995). 
88   San  Diego’s  vehicle  habitation  ordinance  does  not  satisfy  the 
99 requirements of the Due Process Clause.  As written, the vehicle habitation ordinance 
1100 makes  unlawful  the  use  of  a  vehicle  parked  or  standing  on  the  street  as  “either 
1111 temporary or permanent living quarters, abode, or place of habitation.”  None of the 
1122 terms used—“temporary living quarters,” “permanent living quarters,” “abode” or 
1133 “place of habitation”—are defined anywhere in the ordinance. 
1144   The City’s vehicle habitation ordinance (whether enforced directly or 
1155 indirectly through citations issued under “Violation of Signs” prohibiting habitation) 
1166 fails  to  provide  adequate  notice  and  sufficient  guidance,  which  would  allow  an 
1177 individual to ascertain beyond mere speculation as to how one uses a parked or 
1188 standing vehicle as “either temporary or permanent living quarters, abode, or place of 
1199 habitation.”  The ordinance therefore fails “to draw a clear line between innocent and 
2200 criminal conduct,” Desertrain v. City of Los Angeles, 754 F. 3d 1147, 1156 (9th Cir. 
2211 2014), and invites selective enforcement against people who are homeless, many of 
2222 whom have disabilities.  As detailed above, Named Plaintiffs and Class members have 
2233 attempted to comply with the vehicle habitation ordinance but have nonetheless been 
2244 ticketed under its vague and overbroad reach. 
2255   The  vehicle  habitation  ordinance  should  therefore  be  declared 
2266 unconstitutionally vague both on its face and as applied against Named Plaintiffs and 
2277 Class members in violation of substantive due process protections under the Fourteenth 
2288 Amendment to the U.S. Constitution.

22   Title II of the ADA, 42 U.S.C. § 12132, provides that: 
33 [N]o qualified individual with a disability shall, by reason of such disability, be 
44 excluded  from  participation  in  or  be  denied  the  benefits  of  the  services,

88 persons with disabilities” as defined under the ADA.  42 U.S.C. § 12102; 42 U.S.C. 
99 § 12131; 28 C.F.R. § 35.104. 
1100   Under  the  ADA’s  broad  language,  a  “program,  service,  or  activity” 
1111 includes within its scope “anything a public entity does.”  Yeskey v. Pennsylvania Dep’t 
1122 of Corr., 118 F. 3d 168, 171 & n. 5 (3d Cir. 1997), aff’d 524 U.S. 206 (1998) (quoting 
1133 28 C.F.R. Pt. 35, App. A, preamble to ADA regulations).

1166   In addition, the various amenities of City life offered to its residents, 
1177 including San Diego’s parks, beaches and public events are “services, programs, or 
1188 activities” of the City. 
1199   Title II protects people with disabilities against facially neutral policies 
2200 that burden people with disabilities more than others, by requiring that the public entity 
2211 provide reasonable modifications to avoid the discrimination unless the public entity 
2222 can demonstrate that such modifications would result in a fundamental alteration of the 
2233 program.  28 C.F.R. § 35.130(b)(7); Crowder v. Kitagaw, 81 F. 3d 1480 (9th Cir. 1996). 
2244   Reasonable modifications can adjust for the financial limitations that arise 
2255 from a disability, not just the immediate manifestations of the impairment giving rise 
2266 to the disability.  Giebeler v. M & B Associates, 343 F. 3d 1143, 1152 (9th Cir. 2003).

2288 herein to allow Named Plaintiffs and Disability Subclass members to legally park their

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 352     Filed 03/10/25     PageID.7230     Page 1
of 9
 
1  Ann E. Menasche, SB #74774 
ann@bulldogforjustice.com 
2 
LAW OFFICE OF ANN E. MENASCHE 
3  1901 First Avenue, Suite 100 
San Diego, CA 92101

Telephone: (619) 798-6835

Attorneys for Plaintiffs 
6 
 
7   
 
8 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
9 
SOUTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
10 
 
11  MICHAEL BLOOM, STEPHEN  Case No. 3:i17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB   
CHATZKY, TONY DIAZ, VALERIE 
12 
GRISCHY, PENNY HELMS, 
13 
BENJAMIN HERNANDEZ, DOUG  MOTION FOR ENFORCEMENT 
OF SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT 
14  HIGGINS, SUZONNE KEITH, 
RE: SIGNS; REQUEST FOR 
GERALD STARK, ANNA STARK, 
15 
ATTORNEYS’ FEES 
and DAVID WILSON, individually 
 
16 
and on behalf of themselves and all 
 
17  others similarly situated,  
 
           Plaintiffs, 
18   
   
 
19  vs. 
 
 
20   
CITY OF SAN DIEGO, 
 
21 
  Defendant. 
22 
23 
________ ____________________ 
24 
25 
26   
27   
28 
Bloom, et al. v. City of San Diego, Case No. 3:17-CV-02324-AJB-DEB  1 
Motion for Enforcement of Settlement Agreement 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 352     Filed 03/10/25     PageID.7231     Page 2
of 9
 
1 
MOTION FOR ENFORCEMENT OF SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT 
2 
Plaintiff(s), by and through their undersigned counsel, respectfully move this 
3 
Court for an order enforcing the Settlement Agreement (Doc. No. 329-2) reached 
4 
between the parties in this matter and instructing the Defendant(s) to remove or 
5 
modify the signs currently posted in accordance with the intent and terms of the 
6 
settlement. In support of this motion, Plaintiff(s) state as follows: 
7 
STATEMENT OF FACTS 
8 
A. Issue in Dispute 
9 
On October 10, 2024, the Court issued final approval of the parties’ 
10 
Settlement Agreement (Doc. No. 329-2), and jurisdiction to enforce the Agreement 
11 
for three years was delegated to Magistrate Judge Butcher. Despite the terms of the 
12 
Settlement Agreement, however, the City has refused to modify or remove both the 
13 
VHO and OVO signs. Because the signs remain unchanged, they misstate and 
14 
misalign with the terms of the Agreement and mislead class members about their 
15 
rights under the Agreement. The City has refused to remove or modify the signage. 
16 
B. Current Signage: 
17 
OVO signs, posted throughout the city, currently state in relevant part: "NO 
18 
PARKING ALL CITY STREETS OVERSIZED VEHICLES (EXCEEDING 27' 
19 
LONG AND 7' HIGH) NON-MOTORIZED VEHICLES RECREATIONAL 
20 
VEHICLES 2AM-6AM EXCEPT BY CITY PERMIT." Chatsky Decl. Exh. A. 
21 
VHO signs observed posted throughout the area of Mission Bay where many 
22 
class members park, currently state: "HABITATION IN VEHICLE PROHIBITED 
23 
FROM 9PM TO 6AM," while others read, "HABITATION IN VEHICLE 
24 
PROHIBITED AT ANY TIME." Menasche Decl., Exhs. E to K. 
25 
C. Efforts to Resolve the Issue 
26 
Plaintiffs, through counsel, have made extensive efforts to ensure the City’s 
27 
compliance with the Settlement Agreement by addressing the improper signage 
28 
Bloom, et al. v. City of San Diego, Case No. 3:17-CV-02324-AJB-DEB  2 
Motion for Enforcement of Settlement Agreement 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 352     Filed 03/10/25     PageID.7232     Page 3
of 9
 
1 
and ticketing practices. Plaintiffs participated with the City in multiple meetings 
2 
over many months in an effort to resolve these issues without court intervention. 
3 
Despite notice and good faith attempts to resolve these violations, the City has 
4 
refused to take corrective action. 
5 
Section 11 of the Settlement Agreement states in part, “It is the intent of the 
6 
Parties that any disputes concerning the interpretation or implementation of this 
7 
Agreement be solved as swiftly and inexpensively as possible, initially through 
8 
communication among counsel for the Parties, and, in the event such 
9 
communication does not result in resolution, submission of the dispute for 
10 
resolution by the Court.” Settlement Agreement at 7, § 11, Doc. No. 329-2. It 
11 
further states, “To the extent non-compliance is identified, the responding Party 
12 
will have 45 days to cure the non-compliance (or identify a plan to cure any non-
13 
compliance). If the Parties are unable to resolve the Dispute within 45 days of the 
14 
Notice of Dispute, the Party that served the Notice of Dispute may thereafter 
15 
petition the Court through Judge Butcher for resolution of the Dispute, according 
16 
to such procedures as the Court may direct.” Id. 
17 
On October 30, 2024, Plaintiffs’ counsel Ann Menasche and Scott Dreher 
18 
met with Deputy City Attorney Jacqueline McQuarrie and formally notified her 
19 
that current city signage prohibiting vehicle habitation was inconsistent with the 
20 
terms of the Settlement Agreement. Meeting minutes confirm Plaintiffs’ counsel 
21 
raised concerns, specifically stating: “The signs that say, ‘No Vehicle Habitation’ 
22 
are inconsistent with the Settlement Agreement, which expressly allows vehicle 
23 
habitation in most circumstances.” See Menasche Decl., Exh. A (Email to 
24 
Jacqueline McQuarrie(Oct. 30, 2024, 11:57 AM.) 
25 
On November 4, 2024, Ms. Menasche and her law clerk met with a class 
26 
member and toured the area of Mission Bay, taking photos of No Vehicle 
27 
Habitation signs. Later that day, Ms. Menasche sent an email to Ms. McQuarrie 
28 
Bloom, et al. v. City of San Diego, Case No. 3:17-CV-02324-AJB-DEB  3 
Motion for Enforcement of Settlement Agreement 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 352     Filed 03/10/25     PageID.7233     Page 4
of 9
 
1 
with copies of photos that were taken. Menasche Decl. Exh. B. On November 25, 
2 
2024, Plaintiffs’ counsel submitted a formal proposal to the City to modify the 
3 
language as an alternative to removing the signage. Ms. Menasche wrote: “Here is 
4 
our proposed language for amending the VHO and OVO signs. 1. VHO signs now 
5 
reads: ’Vehicle habitation is prohibited at all times’, add except for people whose 
6 
only shelter is their vehicles. 2. OVO sign [], add: ‘Except for people whose only 
7 
shelter is their vehicle and no spot in safe parking program is reasonably available. 
8 
The other acceptable alternative is to take them down.” Menasche Decl., Exh. C, 
9 
(Email to Jacqueline McQuarrie, Nov. 25, 2024, 9:37 AM. 
10 
At a meeting between Plaintiffs’ Counsel and the City attorney’s office on 
11 
December 21, 2024, Plaintiffs reiterated their concerns and requested yet another 
12 
response from the City regarding the signage modifications. However, the City 
13 
refused to either amend or take down the signs. Meeting minutes confirm “The 
14 
City does not agree to amend or remove the VHO and OVO signs as Plaintiffs 
15 
requested.” Menasche Decl. Exh. D, (Email to Jacqueline McQuarrie, Dec. 21, 
16 
2024, 2:32 PM) 
17 
Plaintiffs have exhausted every reasonable avenue to bring the City into 
18 
compliance with the Settlement Agreement. Despite multiple notices, meetings, 
19 
and a formal proposal for modification, the City has refused to take corrective 
20 
action. Plaintiffs have acted in good faith, complied with Section 11 of the 
21 
Settlement Agreement, including giving 45 days to resolve the dispute, and have 
22 
provided the City with every opportunity to rectify its non-compliance. Given the 
23 
impasse, Plaintiffs now seek judicial enforcement of the Settlement Agreement to 
24 
compel the City’s compliance with its obligations by either removing or modifying 
25 
the VHO and OVO signs. 
26 
/// 
27 
/// 
28 
Bloom, et al. v. City of San Diego, Case No. 3:17-CV-02324-AJB-DEB  4 
Motion for Enforcement of Settlement Agreement 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 352     Filed 03/10/25     PageID.7234     Page 5
of 9
 
1 
Intent of the Settlement Agreement 
2 
The primary intent of the Settlement Agreement between the parties is to 
3 
decriminalize living in one’s vehicle under the VHO, and to prevent the ticketing 
4 
of oversized vehicles of class members for nighttime parking under the OVO when 
5 
no reasonable parking options are available. This includes retroactive justice in the 
6 
form of ticket forgiveness for parking violations related to the OVO and VHO 
7 
which is in the process of being completed. These provisions enable class members 
8 
to—lawfully—park their vehicles with narrow exceptions without the threat of 
9 
receiving tickets under the OVO or being subjected to criminal citations or arrest 
10 
under the VHO. 
11 
The intent of the Settlement Agreement is clearly demonstrated throughout 
12 
its provisions. For example, Section 3 states, “The parties agree that the amended 
13 
VHO training bulletin is intended to prevent VHO enforcement against Plaintiffs 
14 
and class members who are sheltering in, resting in, sleeping in, or storing property 
15 
in their vehicles, provided they are otherwise law-abiding and not committing any 
16 
criminal law violations, other than the VHO." Settlement Agreement at 2, § 3. 
17 
Further, Section 2 specifies, “… the City shall promptly forgive all unpaid OVO 
18 
tickets for parking oversized vehicles between 2 a.m. and 6 a.m. and for violations 
19 
of signage related to VHO or OVO requirements during nighttime hours received 
20 
by class members…” Settlement Agreement at 1, § 2. 
21 
An additional intent of the settlement is shown through the limitations 
22 
placed in OVO enforcement while the City expands its Safe Parking Program. The 
23 
agreement states, “The City’s intent is to provide safe parking during nighttime 
24 
hours that OVO and VHO would be enforced.” Settlement Agreement at 3, § 1 
25 
(Oct. 10, 2024). Enforcement of the OVO is subject to specific limitations to 
26 
protect individuals who use their vehicles as their primary shelter. The Settlement 
27 
states, “… If there is no safe parking available … the city will not enforce the 
28 
Bloom, et al. v. City of San Diego, Case No. 3:17-CV-02324-AJB-DEB  5 
Motion for Enforcement of Settlement Agreement 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 352     Filed 03/10/25     PageID.7235     Page 6
of 9
 
1 
nighttime provisions of the OVO and VHO at that time.”  Settlement Agreement at 
2 
3, § 2. Legal nighttime parking is considered unavailable when the City's 
3 
designated Safe Parking Lots are full, closed, or when no spot is reasonably 
4 
available to the individual, taking into account factors such as the type of vehicle, 
5 
distance to the lot, and whether there is adequate space for the vehicle. A critical 
6 
aspect of the settlement is the requirement for the City to provide daily updates on 
7 
the availability of spaces in these Safe Parking Lots. However, as of now, the City 
8 
has not yet established the necessary website to disseminate this information. 
9 
Consequently, without a reliable method for individuals to verify the availability of 
10 
legal parking options, the enforcement of the OVO is effectively suspended until 
11 
the City fulfills its obligations under the Settlement Agreement. 
12 
Even with a functioning website, right now there are no spaces available for 
13 
class members with oversized vehicles. The one Safe Lot open to oversized 
14 
vehicles located at Mission Valley is at capacity. The new Safe Lot that is supposed 
15 
to open, the H-Barracks, is tied up in litigation. 
16 
The intent of these provisions is unambiguous: to decriminalize living in 
17 
one’s vehicle under the VHO, prohibiting OVO ticketing when no reasonable 
18 
parking options are available, and establishing additional lawful parking locations 
19 
for class members. The goal is to ensure that class members can lawfully park in 
20 
the City without the threat of ticketing or arrest. 
21 
However, this intent is frustrated by Defendant(s) because the signs posted 
22 
throughout the city do not reflect the terms of the Settlement Agreement. As a 
23 
result, class members are actively misled as to their legal right to park their 
24 
oversized vehicles at night or to use their vehicle for shelter and not be subjected to 
25 
criminal persecution, undermining the purpose of the Settlement. Moreover, tickets 
26 
under the nighttime provisions of the OVO have continued to be issued after the 
27 
settlement was approved on October 10, 2024, further signaling to class members 
28 
Bloom, et al. v. City of San Diego, Case No. 3:17-CV-02324-AJB-DEB  6 
Motion for Enforcement of Settlement Agreement 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 352     Filed 03/10/25     PageID.7236     Page 7
of 9
 
1 
that they are not permitted to park their RV or camper at night, contrary to the 
2 
terms of the Settlement.1 
3 
Good Faith Performance and Implied Obligations 
4 
In addition to the express terms of the Settlement Agreement, the doctrine of 
5 
good faith and fair dealing requires that the parties perform their obligations in 
6 
good faith. This duty includes the removal or modification of city signs that 
7 
contradict the Agreement's intent. 
8 
As the California Supreme Court explained, “In every contract, there is an 
9 
implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing that neither party will do anything 
10 
which injures the right of the other to receive the benefits of the agreement.” 
11 
Brown v. Superior Court, 34 Cal. 2d 559, 212 P.2d 878 (1949). Furthermore, the 
12 
law holds that “[A]ll things that in law or usage are considered as incidental to a 
13 
contract, or as necessary to carry it into effect, are implied therefrom, unless some 
14 
of them are expressly mentioned therein, when all other things of the same class 
15 
are deemed to be excluded.” Cal. Civ. Code § 1656 (West 2024). 
16 
Defendant(s)’ failure to modify or remove the signs, prohibiting vehicle 
17 
habitation and nighttime oversized vehicle parking despite the Settlement 
18 
Agreement’s clear intent to severely limit the enforcement of the VHO and OVO, 
19 
breaches the implied duty of good faith. The purpose of the Settlement was to 
20 
allow otherwise law-abiding class members to live in their vehicles without risking 
21 
citation or arrest under the VHO and to park oversized vehicles at night as long as 
22 
no reasonable options for parking are available without the threat of ticketing 
23 
under the OVO. The unaltered signs, which mislead class members and the public 
24 
and continue to cause confusion, directly undermine that objective. 
25 
26   
1 The City has conceded that these OVO tickets were issued by mistake. Plaintiffs understand that these tickets will 
27  not be processed and/or will be automatically forgiven, though Plaintiffs have not yet received confirmation that this 
has occurred. 
28 
Bloom, et al. v. City of San Diego, Case No. 3:17-CV-02324-AJB-DEB  7 
Motion for Enforcement of Settlement Agreement 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 352     Filed 03/10/25     PageID.7237     Page 8
of 9
 
1 
By failing to act in a manner consistent with the purpose of the Agreement, 
2 
Defendant(s) are frustrating the Agreement's very intent—ensuring that class 
3 
members can park and live in their vehicles legally and without fear of 
4 
enforcement of the VHO and OVO ordinances. This failure to correct the signage 
5 
is a breach of the implied obligation to act in good faith, as it prevents class 
6 
members from fully enjoying the benefits of the Settlement. Therefore, the City 
7 
must take immediate corrective action to ensure the signs reflect the true intent of 
8 
the Agreement and stop misleading the public. 
9 
Relief Requested 
10 
Plaintiff(s) respectfully request that this Court enforce the Settlement 
11 
Agreement by ordering Defendant(s) to immediately modify or remove the signs 
12 
that are inconsistent with the terms of the Settlement Agreement.  
13 
Attorney's Fees 
14 
Plaintiff(s) request an award of attorney’s fees associated with the 
15 
enforcement of the Settlement Agreement. Pursuant to provision 10 of the 
16 
Settlement Agreement, Plaintiff(s) believe that the funds allocated for enforcement 
17 
should be used to cover these fees and costs. In the alternative, Plaintiff(s) request 
18 
that the Court order Defendant(s) to reimburse Plaintiff(s) for the fees incurred in 
19 
bringing this motion. 
20 
Conclusion 
21 
For the reasons set forth above, including the failure of Defendant(s) to act 
22 
in good faith and to perform under the Settlement Agreement, Plaintiff(s) 
23 
respectfully request that this Court enter an order enforcing the terms of the  
24 
/// 
25 
/// 
26 
/// 
27 
/// 
28 
Bloom, et al. v. City of San Diego, Case No. 3:17-CV-02324-AJB-DEB  8 
Motion for Enforcement of Settlement Agreement 

Case 3:17-cv-02324-AJB-DEB     Document 352     Filed 03/10/25     PageID.7238     Page 9
of 9
 
1 
Settlement Agreement and mandating that Defendant(s) modify or remove the 
2 
signs in question.  
3 
 
4 
 
5   March 4, 2025 
 Respectfully submitted, 
6 
 
7     
  /s/ Ann E. Menasche
